comments.commentBody: With managers and other likeminded individuals that are stupid enough to hire someone working over someone out of work, those that are unemployed are left with few choices.

On the Italian Island of Procida they use the rind of very large sweet lemons..(not sure we have that type of varietal) for a salad..simply mix with olive oil, mint leaves and a bit of crushed hot pepper..a delicious salad

I am just learning how to pickle watermelon rind--cut off the fruity red portion to eat and the hard green outer section (about 6 pounds).  Cut into bite sized chunks (or shapes!) then place in a ball with 3/4 cup pickling salt and 3 quarts of water.  Cover with ice cubes and let sit for 4 hours or so.  Drain, rinse and cover with clean cold water and cook until you can put a fork in them (tender, not mushy).  Then, combine 9 cups sugar and 3 cups vinegar and your favorite bread and butter pickling spices in a spice bag--boil for a few minutes.  Pour spices out of bag over your watermelon and put in fridge overnight.  The next day, gently cook for 1 hour, pack into jars and process pint jars for 10 minutes to seal.
What about pesticides and other contaminants in peelings?  I wonder about the oranges I buy---the zest is tasty in salads and baking, but, how healthy is it in terms of contaminants?

I wonder about the efficiency, healthfulness, and originality of one suggestion in the article: "Deep-fry large pieces of [potato] peel in 350-degree oil and sprinkle with salt and paprika."

For home cooks, deep-frying is mainly an expensive waste of a large quantity of oil: the heat will break the oil down so it won't keep long enough to use repeatedly. Deep frying isn't very healthy: another reason not to do it often enough to justify the use of the oil (unless you are running a fast food outlet and reselling it as auto fuel). Finally, using potato skins this way is -- or maybe used to be -- a kind of restaurant fad, no more original than making stock from vegetable scraps. Remember those crunchy deep-fried "potato skins" loaded with cheese, bacon-like crumbles, and sour cream?

I just bake or boil potatoes in their jackets and eat the whole thing. Not original either. But no waste.

I just made a pesto of sorts with celery leaves, carrot and radish greens, pea leaves, mint, basil, and a few other herbs a friend gave me, with a smoked gorgonzola dolce and cashews. It's more bitter and vegetal than a traditional basil pesto, so the blue cheese added a necessary creaminess and hint of sweetness.
And in late summer, when I roast and freeze or can pounds of tomatoes and red bell peppers, the skins get bottled with olive oil and herb stems for an amazingly summery vinagrette base.
The steak is good. Now I see I am not the only one smoking the cigar on my way home!!!

After joining a CSA this summer, we can't bear to see any of the amazing leaves, tops, stems, etc. from our amazing produce thrown in the trash. Early in the season it was hard because we were getting a lot of lettuce, kale, arugula, etc. in addition to the tops of radishes, carrots and the like. We ate a lot of salads. But now things have evened out. Celery leaves are one of my favorite things in the world. A while back I saw a recipe in Gourmet for a mushroom carpaccio topped with celery leaves, shaved pecorino, olive oil and a bit of salt and pepper. Now I make it all the time. Chopped stems, like swiss chard stems, are great in a vegetable soup, or you can roast them. I also like to cook them quickly with some soy sauce, lime and sesame seeds. Swapping some basil for bitter greens, like radish tops, in a pesto gives it a more interesting flavor. And you can add any of it to a stir fry.

Corn cobs: "milk" by running a spoon over the shucked cobs and/or simmer cobs in water (add the corn milk) that you'll use for making polenta or grits.

Kale ribs: chop finely (first cut each rib in half lengthwise) and saute with onions in butter. Use in a frittata.

Carrot tops:I used to make carrot top soup (recipe below) but stopped when I heard that carrot tops are somewhat poisonous.
http://topics.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/13/the-toxic-salad/

Ingredients:
· 1 Tbsp. olive oil or butter
· ½ onion, diced
· 4 cups water or stock
· 4 medium carrots, cut into ¼ inch rounds
· 1 cup carrot tops, finely chopped
· ½ cup quinoa, rinsed
salt and pepper to taste (and maybe tamari if using water)

Sauté the onion until translucent, add the remaining ingredients and simmer for 15- 20 minutes.

I don't think this is a cynical theory. I think it's 100% true. If the economy improves by late 2012 Obama in a landslide. Tea Party/Republicans want things to be bad, that's exactly why they're delaying the approval of the debt ceiling increase as long as possible! The rich/wealthy are not hurting now, it's the poor/middle class getting killed so why should rich/wealth/care care?...The worse things are the better for them.

There is a sort of GOP conspiracy at work, only not primarily the one Ms. Rampell refers to and that some apparently believe in. Rather, it's the same one the Republicans have been fomenting for years: Maintain and even worsen the deficits and debt in order to force the dismantling of the government programs they hate--the ones that help people other than the rich: Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security. That these (a) ARE government programs and (b) help middle and lower income people is reason enough to kill them. That's Republican religion. As it happens, I buy the other conspiracy theory as well: Can anyone actually imagine the Republicans wanting the economy to improve when there's a Democrat in the White House and an election approaching?

To my mind nothing quite beats the  versatility of the fava. I buy them dried for 99 cents a pound at Lebanese food stores. They are so tolerant of cold you can plant them by pulling back the snow and even in Michigan can grow outdoors from April to November. From one to 12 inches tall the leaves are delicious raw in salads and sandwiches. Taller than that and the leaves are large enough for cooking like any green similar to spinach. When the pods first appear before the beans form they can be cooked like green beans. A week or two after that and the pods with small beans are great grilled with olive oil and salt, ten minutes a side eaten whole for a smoky edamame type treat. When the beans are mature but fresh they can be grilled in the shell for popping out, or popped out to eat raw on french bread with butter and maybe a thin slice of fresh garlic and salt. Fresh green favas are an excellent shell bean, perhaps best in brodo, just simmered in chicken broth with a grating of parmesan and a little parsley. Finally, of course, full circle to dried form, they are excellent boiled and mashed with garlic, olive oil, lemon and parsley as foul medemmes, a hummus type breakfast mash to have with pita bread. Favas come in large, medium and small varieties. I prefer to grow the small ones as the beans do not need to have the skin peeled before eating, as with the medium and large varieties. Almost no pests or diseases bother them (although you can grow them as a catch crop to distract june bugs from your other crops - favas can withstand an avalanche of june bugs and still survive and produce a crop) and they are tolerant of all the cold and heat that Michigan spring, summer and fall can throw at them. Just beware that some people are genetically predisposed to favism and cannot eat them without getting sick, so eat only a small amount the first few times till  you are certain  you can tolerate them. If you can, it's a miracle veg, or really, several miracle veges.
I have to agree with with Carol Adams.  Steakhouses are a shameless and tacky celebration of greed and cruelty.  Where is the progress?
...or you could just compost...
Great series - very nicely photographed and compiled.  Thanks!

Thanks so much for this. The news we read about NK is almost always grotesquely exaggerated and very bad. Photo essays like this remind us that even in conditions of deprivation humanity will find a way to flourish as it may.

This is ridiculous. Heat sensors won't work because young children are required to be in car seats. If the technology should be incorporated into anything it should be car seats.

What about adults in the back seats of cars? Adults, and older children, capable of getting out cars if they're uncomfortable often ride in the backseat, and may not want to exit the car immediately when it's turned off. People often wait in a car while someone runs in to get something, and the car shouldn't decide that's unsafe because in some circumstances it is.

It's unsafe for someone to be in the backseat while the car is off if 1) it's hot and sunny or cold, and the person isn't dressed for the weather and 2) the person is incapable of getting out of the car on their own. Can't we just trust humans to make responsible decisions, instead of using technology that doesn't understand the factors that should be considered when making the decision?

I consider myself very fortunate to have been recently hired (at the age of 52) for a part-time IT position. I never qualified for unemployment because I had been a college student, returned to school after many years in construction trades. Do I have any gov't agency or employment search to thank for my job? No, a fellow soccer dad got me the interview. And even then, the question came up: "Why are you still unemployed after a year and a half of looking?" What could I do but shrug? The final irony is that this is a defense contractor job. That's right, it's dependent on taxpayer money to support our troops.
The "wealth creators" are not the rich, they are middle-class managers and entrepreneurs who have a mission or a vision they need to accomplish, and DEMAND for whatever they're doing.

With all due respect, do you recall the following?:

Astounding work!

Nice work David. But I don't see that you guys had "unprecedented access" or that you were free of government minders. Do you really think the North Korean journalists didn't have to report on your every move? Being able to carry cell phones was unusual as everybody else must surrender these upon arrival at the airport. Shooting well in DPRK requires imagination and creative skill and I think you nailed it.

The writer sees only the small picture. The conspiracy - if you will - is not about something so small as the 2012 election. The grander scheme is a money grab by the ruling corporations and the vastly wealthy as the middle class disappears and the US as a super power begins a long slow decline. The republicans are both agents and pawns for the corporate powers that own the government.

I am compelled to address some of the comments brought up. On the point of working for free, we are excited to be testing with a small group to see how to tackle the incentive/gamification issue and make the project as interesting as possible to all parties. The reason we chose to reach out to our social media followers is that we found our followers to be some of the most engaged photography enthusiasts and with the sheer numbers could bring immense value to the Magnum archive and allow us to carry on the legacy of documentary photography. We, in no way wish to exploit rather we want to foster engagement in an industry that has suffered a huge blow in recent years. Magnum is not immune, but we truly believe Magnum must remain an active participant in the conversation of photojournalism and a relevant partner in stimulating this discourse. Regarding Dell, MSD Capital purchased a select press print archive and endowed it to the Ransom Center at UT for scholarly research and open to the public that wishes to engage with the historical imagery, they did not buy the Magnum photo archive,copyright,or reproduction rights. You can learn more about it here: http://agency.magnumphotos.com/about/news#MAGNEWS ​If you have any questions or concerns please feel free to email me at myoung@magnumphotos.com

The Credit Agencies have spoken.
Because the world is watching.
The Fact is : We simply cannot jeopardize our credit rating.

What most people fail to understand is how critical the credit rating of the US is to the health and stability of the global financial system, purely from a mathematical standpoint; when such math is challenged, it will lead to a crisis in confidence on an untested scale.

The industry veterans understand the singular foundation to finance is and always has been the "risk free rate" as defined by the US Treasury market. All day-to-day money market transactions price off of it. Every capital market relies upon it such as stocks, bonds, commodities, currencies etc. Everyone and every institution who borrows depend on it. Models are explicitly tied while confidence in liquidity and stability in pricing are implicit. Perhaps the biggest bomb to drop would be a forced re-pricing and potential unwinding of the $700 TRILLION of notional derivatives that exist on financial books of corporations and governments.
Thus Ben Bernanke chose to warn of a "calamitous" effect.

And if readers here no longer respect the FED, then please take to heart these words from Jamie Dimon: "And what surprises me about the conversation at all isn’t — you can talk about all the potential catastrophic outcomes, but I — no one can possibly say, in my opinion who is semi-rational, could possibly say that there’s no chance of a catastrophic outcome. And therefore why would you take that risk?”

We all need "the big deal".
Notice how there are no trees as soon as you get outside of the capital. People in NK have been cutting down trees to use as a fuel source due to their serious and longterm economic hardship.
